Andrew McDonagh wrote:
> Jason Rogers wrote:
> 
>  >2. In my opinion, this isn't something that can break.  Instead I 
> would test
>  >the super class implementation.  On that same note, why do you even have
>  >these methods here?  Are you opening up the access level (from default or
>  >protected to public)?
> 
> As someone who practises TDD  I would have written the test first, then
> implemented the derived class.  Then possibly refactored the derive
> class to call the base class method, then further refactored the derived
> class to remove the overridden method, seeing as it now does nothing.
> 
> However, after all of this, I'm still testing the public interface of
> the derived class.

Unnecessarily so.

> Then if the derived class is refactored again to do something additional
> to the super class, our existing test will let know if anything is
> broken. Also, if we refactor the super class because of some need of
> another derived class, we know whether we have broken any derived
> classes assumptions of how the super class works.

Are you prepared have n+1 copies of the tests for a given superclass 
method, one for the superclass and one for each of the n known 
subclasses? I'm not.

I change the test to work with the superclass, and when (in the future) 
I change the subclass's implementation, I would test-drive the new 
behavior, (re)creating the tests I need.
